channel.title: JavaScript Weekly
channel.description: A newsletter of JavaScript articles, news and cool projects

item.title: ã€The latest on Oracle's hold on JavaScriptã€‘Oracleå…³äºJavaScriptçš„æœ€æ–°æŒæœ‰
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹750 â€” August 29, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

An Illustrated Guide to Big O and Time Complexity â€” A fantastic JavaScript-oriented, interactive, visual essay about Big O notation and its role in describing algorithmic complexity. This is a beautiful bit of work, even if youâ€™re already wise to O(log n) and O(n^2).

Sam Rose

ğŸ’¡ Sam is making a name for himself with his interactive essays â€“ check out the load balancing, memory allocation, hashing, and bloom filter ones too.

JavaScriptâ€™s Trademark Problem â€” Dr. Axel discusses Oracle's hold over the â€˜JavaScriptâ€™ trademark, including the history and present-day legal attempts to challenge Oracle. Fireship has also just published â–¶ï¸Â a video about the battle and thereâ€™s now a GoFundMe to raise funds to continue theÂ fight.

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer et al.

Tests Are Dead. Meticulous AI Is Here â€” Meticulous creates and maintains a continuously evolving E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Built on Chromium with a deterministic engine, itâ€™s the only testing tool that eliminates flakes. Relied on by Dropbox, Notion, and Wiz.

Meticulous AI sponsor

New in ESLint v9.34.0: Multithread Linting â€” A common feature of tools like Rslint, Biome, and Oxlint, is being 'Nx times faster' than ESLint, but the latest ESLint has a trick up its sleeve and can now process multiple files at the same time, dramatically reducing lint times for largeÂ projects.

Francesco Trotta

IN BRIEF:

  • Daniel Rosenwasser proposes that TypeScript 6.0 should have --strict on byÂ default. You can learn more about what's planned for TypeScript 6.0 here.

  • Malicious versions of Nx, along with some supporting plugin packages, were published to npm â€“ more details on affected versions.

  • Remix v3 is set to drop React, instead using its own fork of Preact.

  • Codecs are a new Zod API for defining bidirectional transformations between twoÂ types.

  • ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ CascadiaJS is a conference taking place September 18-19 in Seattle,Â WA.

RELEASES:

  • Rspack 1.5 â€“ The fast web bundler improves barrel file optimization, has a faster file system watcher, improved browser support, andÂ more. It's a bigÂ release.

  • Node.js v24.7.0 (Current) â€“ A step forward for cryptography, both with Web Cryptography API support and post-quantumÂ standards.

  • Electron 37.4, Prisma 6.15.0, Ink 6.2.3

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

Speeding Up the JavaScript Ecosystem: Semver â€” The latest in Marvinâ€™s multi-year series of posts on optimizing heavily used parts of the JavaScript ecosystem: â€œDuring the installation process, package managers run a bunch of semver comparisons. The semver library used in npm, yarn and pnpm can be made around 33xÂ faster.â€

Marvin Hagemeister

Say Bye with JavaScript Beacon â€” The Beacon API has been supported in all mainstream browsers for years now and provides a way to send a guaranteed (even if a page is being unloaded) non-blocking request to a web server when no response isÂ needed.

HemathKumar R

Secure Your AI Agents So That You Can Protect Your Users â€” Whether you have a B2B or B2C use case, Auth0 is a full IdP that provides robust security like MFA and continuous threatÂ monitoring.

Auth0 sponsor

How We Migrated Our Monorepo to Node Type Stripping â€” Since v23.6 (and in LTS since v22.18.0), Node has supported running (most) TypeScript code by stripping the types out first. One team shares the challenges encountered and what the endÂ benefitsÂ were.

Stuart Dotson (Calm)

You No Longer Need JavaScript (For Many Frontend Things) â€” A neat look at some of what plain HTML and CSS can achieve in terms of effects and techniques for which you might have once relied uponÂ JavaScript.

Lyra

ğŸ“„ Understanding Promise.any(): When One Success is Enough â€“ Given multiple promises, resolve as soon as just oneÂ fulfills. Matt Smith

ğŸ“„ The Struggle of Wrapping a JavaScript Game for Desktop â€“ The author explains why they finally settled on NW.js. JSLegendDev

ğŸ“„ Speeding Up Firefox Local AI Runtime â€“ How Firefox accelerated inference by replacing the WASM-based ONNX runtime that powers Transformers.js with a native C++ counterpart. ZiadÃ©, Adenot, and Guelton

ğŸ“„ Unit Formatting with Intl in JavaScript Raymond Camden

ğŸ“„ Exporting a Cloth Simulation from Blender to an Interactive Three.js Scene Joshua Guo

ğŸ“º Coming in Angular 21: HttpClient Built In by Default Igor Sedov

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Cornerstone3D 4.0: Build Web-Based Medical Imaging Apps â€” A set of JavaScript libraries to build things like this 3D CT scan viewer, PET-CT scan viewer, and much more besides. Thereâ€™s a lot to this project, along with numerousÂ tutorials.

Open Health Imaging Foundation

ImageJS 1.0: Image Processing and Manipulation Library â€” A library for resizing, cropping, filtering, color adjustments, and numerous other image transformations which works in Node.js and the browser (supporting JPEG, PNG, BMP and TIFF â€“ thanks to pure JS dependencies like fast-jpeg and fast-png). v1.0 brings TypeScript support and a more intuitive API. GitHubÂ repo.

ImageJS Team

The Best Way for Web Developers To Track Key User Flows â€” Check out User Journeys, a new approach to connecting technical performance to user engagement in your webÂ apps.

Embrace sponsor

Obs.js: Context-Aware Web Performance for Everyone â€” Uses the Navigator and Battery APIs to get contextual information about your usersâ€™ connection strength and battery status so you can adapt your site/app to the environment or collect the data forÂ analysis.

Harry Roberts

ğŸ“ŠÂ SveltePlot: A Visualization Framework for Svelte â€” Itâ€™s still in alpha but its API is inspired by a similar plotting library by Observable and built on top of D3. There are plenty of examples in theÂ docs.

Gregor Aisch

  • Repomix 1.4 â€“ Pack an entire repository into a single, LLM-friendlyÂ file. v1.4 adds the ability to integrate commitÂ history.

  • MikroORM 6.5 â€“ TypeScript ORM for Node based on Data Mapper, Unit of Work and Identity MapÂ patterns.

  • ğŸ“„ jsPDF 3.0.2 â€“ Client-side JavaScript PDF generation for everyone.

  • Faker 10.0 â€“ Generate fabricated data to your heart'sÂ content.

  • Tiptap 3.3 â€“ Headless, framework-agnostic rich textÂ editor.

  • RxDB 16.18 â€“ Offline-first, reactive database for JSÂ apps.

  • Denops.vim 8.0 â€“ Write Vim/Neovim plugins withÂ Deno.

ğŸÂ Some Bonus Items

  • Intl Playground is a handy site to get a quick look at how the different options on Intl.DateTimeFormat present in realÂ life.

  • ğŸ“º The folks who created the epic, well-produced â–¶ï¸Â Vue.js documentary, â–¶ï¸Â React documentary and â–¶ï¸Â Node.js documentary are back with â–¶ï¸Â a movie-length documentary all about Python.

  • Talking of Python, Pyodide is a port of CPython to WebAssembly that can be used both in the browser and fromÂ Node.js.

  • ğŸ•¹ï¸ Jeff Schomay is creating a JavaScript roguelike game called Thunder Lizard and decided to see what would happen if he used AI to turn his ASCII renders into full graphics live and on-the-fly. Fun, but soundsÂ expensive!

  • GitHub has added WebP image support across its site. It was a little flaky tillÂ now.

  • ğŸµ Need some music for programming? A fantastic design for a text-only site.

Marvin Hagemeister

- è‡ªv23.6ï¼ˆåœ¨ltsä¸­ï¼Œ v22.18.0 ï¼‰ href =â€œ https://javascriptweekly.com/link/173561/rssâ€ style =â€œ colorï¼šï¼ƒ3366aa;â€>é¦–å…ˆå°†ç±»å‹å‰¥ç¦»ã€‚ä¸€ä¸ªå›¢é˜Ÿåˆ†äº«äº†æ‰€é‡åˆ°çš„æŒ‘æˆ˜ä»¥åŠæœ€ç»ˆçš„å¥½å¤„ã€‚

item.title: ã€We still love jQueryã€‘æˆ‘ä»¬ä»ç„¶å–œæ¬¢jQuery
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹749 â€” August 22, 2025

Read on the Web

â˜€ï¸ We're back after a week off, though I'm starting to think we should have taken two weeks off as it's been quite quiet in JavaScript-land this August! Nevertheless, we still have a full issue for you today, so let's get on to it..Â ;-)
__
Peter Cooper, your editor

JavaScript Weekly

Eliminating JavaScript Cold Starts on AWS Lambda â€” Porffor is a rapidly developing ahead-of-time JavaScript compiler with a major benefit being extremely quick process launch times (think sub-millisecond). This is certainly more a taste of the future, and something to experiment with, rather than something you want to imminently deploy intoÂ production.

Oliver Medhurst

Rspack Introduces Rslint, a Fast Linter Written in Go â€” A high-performance JavaScript and TypeScript linter written in Go, and the newest member of the Rspack/Rstack family ofÂ tools.

Sarah Gooding (Socket)

ğŸ’¡ In related news, the Rust-powered Oxlint linter has unveiled a preview of type-aware linting support. Oxlint and Rslint (or Biome) are worth investigating if you're having performance issues with ESLint.

Front-End System Design: Build Scalable UIs â€” Learn browser rendering, DOM performance, state, and UI optimization with real-worldÂ exercises.

Frontend Masters sponsor

jQuery 4.0.0 Release Candidate 1 â€” Version 4.0 of jQuery has reached the â€œwe think this is ready; now poke it with many sticksâ€ stage. While jQuery is still heavily used, we know itâ€™s old-fashioned, but it was so important in the early days of JavaScript Weekly that we have a major soft spot forÂ it!

Timmy Willison

Reflections on the React Community â€” Lee, formerly of Vercel and widely recognized for his influence on Next.js and React, shares candid reflections on the React community, digging into the rise of React Server Components, the tension between commercial and non-commercial priorities, the toll of burnout, and a reminder that, above all, this is still a community ofÂ people.

Lee Robinson

IN BRIEF:

  • Minification Benchmarks is a frequently updated benchmark of different JavaScript minifiers, with cminify being the newestÂ addition.

  • ğŸ•¹ï¸ The latest js13kGames competition is underway. Submissions are due by SeptemberÂ 13.

  • ğŸ¤ Evan You, creator of Vue.js, went on the Stack Overflow podcast to talk about Vue and its ongoingÂ development.

  • Dr. Axel Rauschmayer is taking a break from his deeper technical articles to produce a series of articles for beginners â€“ he's already covered JavaScript numbers, variables, and functions, strings and methods, and arrays.

RELEASES:

  • React Native 0.81 â€“ Say hi to Android 16 support and precompiled iOSÂ builds.

  • Next.js 15.5 â€“ Turbopack builds in beta and stable Node.jsÂ middleware.

  • Bun v1.2.20 â€“ Now with reduced idle CPU usage. v1.3 dueÂ soon.

  • Astro 5.13 , ESLint v9.33.0, Fastify 5.5, pnpm 10.15, Biome 2.2

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

Using the Custom Highlight API â€” The CSS Custom Highlight API offers a way to style text ranges on a document using JavaScript to create the ranges, and CSS to style them. And, as of Firefox 140, all major browsers now support it. This could be great for in-page search or even dynamic syntaxÂ highlighting.

Chris Coyier

The Power of the Intl API: A Definitive Guide to Browser-Native Internationalization â€” Instead of relying on heavy third-party libraries, modern browsers provide JavaScript with the Intl API â€” a powerful, native way to handleÂ internationalization.

Fuqiao Xue

The Best Way for Web Developers to Track Key User Flows â€” Check out User Journeys, a new approach to connecting technical performance to user engagement in your webÂ apps.

Embrace sponsor

Designing Chrome's Built-in AI Web APIs â€” Domenic, a member of the Chrome team at Google, shares some insights into how the APIs around Chromeâ€™s newest AI features wereÂ designed.

Domenic Denicola

â–¶Â Â React Mock Interview: Three Devs Take on a Challenge â€” Three top developers take on the same React challenge to build a form complete with validation. If youâ€™ve got the time for a 50 minute video, this is fun andÂ educational.

Shruti Kapoor

ğŸ“„ How Incorrect Shopify Webhook Parsing Led to Database Deletion â€“ A sneaky problem with an unexpected undefined value being fed to Prisma. One of Prismaâ€™s validation errors did pick it up, however. Ingressr

ğŸ“„ The Problems with Modals, and How to Solve Them in Vue.js Noel De Martin

ğŸ“„ How Bun Made postMessage 500x Faster Jarred Sumner

ğŸ“„ The Future of JavaScript: What Awaits Us JSDev

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Uppy 5.0: A Powerful, Modular JavaScript File Uploader â€” Upload not just from local sources (whether files or a webcam) but also remote services like Dropbox or Google Drive. Integrates with frameworks like React, Vue, Svelte, and Angular, and supports resumable uploads too. GitHubÂ repo.

Transloadit

ğŸ˜„Â Faceclick: A Lightweight Emoji Picker with Keyword Search â€” Includes some interesting details on how it was made moreÂ efficient.

Dave Gauer

Secure Your AI Agents So That You Can Protect Your Users â€” Whether you have a B2B or B2C use case, Auth0 is a full IdP that provides robust security like MFA and continuous threatÂ monitoring.

Auth0 sponsor

Sidequest.js: A New Scalable Job Execution Option for Node.js â€” A scalable background job processor for Node apps that includes a Web-based dashboard, the ability to support multiple backends, and TS-first ergonomics. GitHub repo.

Merencia and Guizzo

Minecraft MCP Server: Let an LLM Take Control of Minecraft â€” A fun way to play around with MCP servers and LLMs. It uses Mineflayer, a JavaScript API for creating Minecraft bots, behind the scenes. The video in the README is cool, showing how Claude and this server can turn a photo of the White House into an in-worldÂ creation.

Yuniko Software

  • Waku 0.25 â€“ The minimal React framework introduces the concept of 'slice components' â€“ a new approach to fine-grained componentÂ rendering.

  • Retire.js 5.3 â€“ A security scanning tool to detect the use of JavaScript libraries with known vulnerabilities in yourÂ project.

  • Ky 1.9 â€“ Simple HTTP client based upon Fetch for browsers, NodeÂ &Â Deno.

  • Repomix 1.3 â€“ Pack an entire repository into a single, LLM-friendlyÂ file.

  • ğŸ—“ï¸ React Date Picker 8.6 â€“ Simple date picker component.Â (Demo.)

  • Flatbush 4.5 â€“ Fast static spatial index for 2D points andÂ rectangles.

  • plotly.js 3.1 â€“ Standalone data visualization library.

  • Chai 6.0 â€“ BDD / TDD assertionÂ framework.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Dropbox, Wiz, Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

ğŸ¤– Faster AI data = smarter agents. Redis 8.2 brings vector sets and search with sub-ms speed. Try it forÂ free.

ğŸÂ Some Bonus Items

  • SmallJS is a Smalltalk-80 implementation that compiles to JavaScript. v1.7 has just been released with support for creating desktop apps usingÂ NW.js.

  • ğŸï¸ Ryan Skinner presents Rari, a demonstration of replacing Node.js with a Rust-powered backend for rendering React server components, and shows off some serious performanceÂ improvements.

  • ğŸš´ Harry Roberts analyzed the performance of the sites for each team in the Tour de France â€“ it's interesting to see some of the things heÂ noticed.

  • If you use AWS at all, this list of 'AWS stuff you think you know that's now wrong' from Corey Quinn is an eye-opener.

  • /^a(1,3)/ == /^(a|aa|aaa)/? A regex equivalence checker.

Chris Coyier

INTL APIï¼šæµè§ˆå™¨æœ¬å›½å›½é™…åŒ–çš„æƒå¨æŒ‡å— - è€Œä¸æ˜¯ä¾é é‡å‹ç¬¬ä¸‰æ–¹åº“ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯ä¸º intl apiæä¾›JavaScriptï¼Œè€Œä¸æ˜¯ intl apiï¼Œä¸€ç§å¼ºå¤§çš„ï¼Œæœ‰åŠ›çš„æœ¬æœºæ¥å¤„ç†å›½é™…åŒ–ã€‚

- æŸ¥çœ‹ç”¨æˆ·æ—…è¡Œï¼Œä¸€ç§å°†æŠ€æœ¯æ€§èƒ½ä¸ç”¨æˆ·å‚ä¸æ‚¨çš„Webåº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºè¿æ¥çš„æ–°æ–¹æ³•ã€‚

Domenic Denicola

â–¶ - ä¸‰ä¸ªé¡¶çº§å¼€å‘äººå‘˜é‡‡å–äº†ç›¸åŒçš„ReactæŒ‘æˆ˜ï¼Œä»¥æ„å»ºéªŒè¯çš„è¡¨å•ã€‚å¦‚æœæ‚¨æœ‰æ—¶é—´è¿›è¡Œ50åˆ†é’Ÿçš„è§†é¢‘ï¼Œè¿™å¾ˆæœ‰è¶£å’Œæ•™è‚²ã€‚

shruti kapoor

ğŸ“„ Ingressr

ğŸ“„ğŸ“„ğŸ“„

ğŸä¸€äº›å¥–åŠ±é¡¹ç›®

  • ğŸï¸Ryanskinner

  • ğŸš´å“ˆé‡ŒÂ·ç½—ä¼¯èŒ¨ï¼ˆHarry Robertsï¼‰

  • å¦‚æœæ‚¨å®Œå…¨ä½¿ç”¨AWSï¼Œ

  • /^aï¼ˆ1,3ï¼‰/==/^ï¼ˆa | aa | aaaï¼‰/ï¼Ÿ

item.title: ã€How JavaScript really evolves, the inside storyã€‘JavaScriptå¦‚ä½•çœŸæ­£å‘å±•ï¼Œå†…éƒ¨æ•…äº‹
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹748 â€” August 8, 2025

Read on the Web

â˜€ï¸ We're taking next week off, so this will be the last issue until Friday, August 22. Just a little summer vacation.
__
Peter Cooper, your editor

JavaScript Weekly

Apache ECharts 6.0: The Powerful Data Visualization Library â€” 12 years on from its first release, ECharts takes another big step forward. Visualization types span from line, bar and pie charts to 3D graphs, calendars and Sankey diagrams. v6 brings an all-new design language, dynamic theme switching, dark mode support, even more chart types, and more. Be sure to enjoy the 100+ demos and the GitHubÂ repo.

Apache Software Foundation

Add Excel-like Spreadsheet Functionality to Your JavaScript Apps â€” SpreadJS is the industry-leading JavaScript spreadsheet for adding advanced spreadsheet features to your enterprise apps. Build finance, analysis, budget, and other apps. Excel I/O, 500+ calc functions, tables, charts, and more. View demosÂ now.

SpreadJS from MESCIUS inc sponsor

Announcing TypeScript 5.9 â€” One of TypeScript's gentlest steps forward, with support for import defer, --module node20, and â€˜expandable hoversâ€™ (below) to see expanded type information in IDEs. We also learn v6.0 will act as a â€˜transition pointâ€™ to get prepared for the Go-powered â€˜native portâ€™ of TypeScript due to arrive as TypeScriptÂ 7.0.

Microsoft

ğŸ’¡ The latest version of VS Code has also just landed with TypeScript 5.9 included and offering the 'expandable hovers' feature, explained in more depthÂ here.

âš–ï¸Â Oracle's Latest Move in the JavaScriptâ„¢ Trademark Case â€” Oracleâ€™s latest response to Denoâ€™s petition to cancel the JavaScript trademark includes a denial of the assertion that â€œthere is broad industry andÂ public consensus that the term â€˜JavaScriptâ€™ is generic.â€ We've beenÂ told!

United States Patent and Trademark Office

IN BRIEF:

  • Sarah Gooding gives an update on the latest proposal advancements at TC39, including Math.sumPrecise, Uint8Array/base64 conversion functions, and Iterator.concat.

  • A mega roundup of What's New in Viteland covering a variety of Vite ecosystem projects including Vite 7, Rolldown, Oxlint, andÂ Vitest.

  • SvelteKit has added an experimental remote functions feature â€“ server-side functions that can be called from anywhere within the SvelteKit app.

  • Vercel now natively supports the deployment of Hono apps. Hono is a lightweight, cross-runtime webappÂ framework.

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

â–¶Â Â How JavaScript Really Evolves: Inside TC39 with Daniel Ehrenberg â€” A well-recorded 47 minute in-person conversation with one of the most productive members of the TC39Â committee covering not just some of the newest features coming to JavaScript, but also the way TC39 works and how you can get involved and propose ideas and help the language moveÂ forward.

The Weekly Dev's Brew

ğŸ’¬ It's very rough, but for accessibility, I've put the raw YouTube transcript in this gist, if you can't watch theÂ video. You can also listen and subscribe in podcast form here.

How V8's JSON.stringify Got Over 2x Faster â€” The V8 team has turbo-charged JSON.stringify, giving apps an automatic performance boost for numerous common tasks when using V8 13.8 onwards (such as in Chrome 138). This article unpacks the low-level work behind theÂ speedup.

Patrick Thier (V8)

Level Up Your Auth for Not Only Your Users, but Also Your AI Agents â€” Auth0 is a full IdP that provides robust security and control over the user experience, from sign-up flows to advancedÂ authorization.

Auth0 sponsor

"JavaScript Isnâ€™t the Problem, Replacing the Browser Was" â€” The creator of RedwoodSDK, a React framework for building server-side apps on Cloudflare, suggests SPA-style development was a compromise to work around platform limitations, and now a server-first approach makes goodÂ sense.

Peter Pistorius

ğŸ“„ Building Bluesky Comments for My Blog â€“ A neat idea, and might give you some ideas of yourÂ own. Natalie B

ğŸ“„ What We Learned From Creating PostCSS Andrey Sitnik (Evil Martians)

ğŸ“„ Introducing Stan: A New State Management Library forÂ TypeScript RafaÅ‚ KrupiÅ„ski

ğŸ“„ A Few Things About the Anchor Elementâ€™s href You Might Not Have Known Jim Nielsen

ğŸ“º tRPC vs oRPC: A Typesafe API Battle Jack Herrington

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

MathJax v4.0: A JS Display Engine for Math in Browsers â€” Several years in the making, MathJax reasserts its position as one of the best Web-based math rendering approaches. There is, of course, a live demo. v4.0 adds more fonts, a better default font, line-breaking support, ESM support, and muchÂ more.

Cervone, Sorge, et al.

Panda CSS 1.0: Modern, Build-Time, Type-Safe CSS-in-JS â€” A DX-focused CSS-in-JS approach from the creator of Chakra UI that offers build-time generated styles and type safety out of the box. It works with Remix, Vite, Next.js, Astro, and even serverÂ components.

Segun Adebayo

The Best Way for Web Developers to Track Key UserÂ Flows â€” Check out User Journeys, a new approach to connecting technical performance to user engagement in your webÂ apps.

Embrace sponsor

zx v8.8: Write Better Shell Scripts with Node.js â€” A popular way to make shell scripting a more pleasant experience in Node with useful wrappers around child_process, argument escaping, and sensible defaults. v8.8 improves zxâ€™s piping story. (Docs.)

Google

ğŸ”ŠÂ React Native Audio API â€” Get the power and flexibility of the Web Audio API in your React Native apps, whether on iOS, Android or the Web. It's explained in much more detail in this blogÂ post.

Software Mansion

  • eslint-plugin-angular 5.0 â€“ ESLint plugin for AngularJS applications, now with ESLint v9Â support.

  • Ghost 6.0 â€“ Node.js-powered indie publishing and bloggingÂ platform.

  • Joi 18.0 â€“ Schema description language and dataÂ validator.

  • ğŸ“ˆ Fuite 5.0.8 â€“ Tool for finding memory leaks in web apps.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Dropbox, Wiz, Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

Did you know we also publish Frontend Focus? It focuses more on the browser end of things: CSS, WebGL, HTML,Â etc.

ğŸÂ Some Bonus Items

  • AwesomeIndex (above) provides a way to search hundreds of 'awesome'-style curated link lists atÂ once. This idea has a lot of potential, as those lists are crammed full of usefulÂ resources.

  • r2dec-js is a JavaScript-based decompiler that converts assembly code into 'pseudo-C' for learningÂ purposes.

  • Bali is an attempt at creating a JavaScript lexer, parser, and interpreter in the NimÂ language.

  • ğŸ‘€ Do you miss ActionScript 3.0 and Flex? No? This week, I learned Apache is keeping the dream alive with ApacheÂ Royale.

  • ğŸ¤– You probably heard that OpenAI released GPT-5, but their developer-oriented intro to GPT-5 was overshadowed, I think, and it goes into some interestingÂ depth. They dropped two open weight modelsÂ too.

  • Today I learned that JSON has a logo.

We're now off for a week, so will be back on Friday, August 22 â€“ see youÂ then!

item.title: ã€Jumbo-sized JavaScript for issue 747ã€‘å·¨å‹å¤§å°çš„JavaScriptç¬¬747æœŸ
item.description:
ã€

âœˆï¸ #â€‹747 â€” August 1, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Observable NotebooksÂ 2.0 Technology Preview â€” The Observable Framework and the new Notebook Kit are just two parts of a rich ecosystem of reactive JavaScript â€˜notebookâ€™-style tools for creating data visualizations (example) and dashboards, originally created by Mike Bostock. This v2 release previews a big step forward with a new notebook file format based on HTML and, for the first time, support for true vanilla JavaScript, complete with the ability to import libraries with import. Hereâ€™s another neat example showing off theÂ potential. There are a lot of parts here, so digÂ in.

Observable, Inc.

CodeRabbitâ€™s Free AI Code Reviews in IDE - VS Code, Cursor, Windsurf â€” Code Rabbit brings AI code reviews to VS Code, Cursor & Windsurf. Get line-by-line reviews, one-click fixes & codebase-aware feedback - all free in your IDE. Seamlessly integrates with git workflows. Install the extension & startÂ reviewing!

CodeRabbit sponsor

The Many JavaScript Runtimes of the Last Decade â€” A fantastic, well-researched look at the myriad of JavaScript runtimes and engines both past and present, from mainstream picks like Node.js and Bun, to cloud platforms and some more obscure â€˜honorable mentionsâ€™. A perfect way to round out your knowledge of JavaScriptâ€™s runtimeÂ story.

Whatever, Jamie

Node.js v22.18 (LTS) Gets Type Stripping by Default â€” We wouldnâ€™t normally feature a minor Node.js LTS release, but this one comes with a big tweak: type stripping/TypeScript support is enabled by default, making node app.ts a reality, much as with Bun orÂ Deno.

Antoine du Hamel

ğŸ’¡ Node v24.5 (Current) has also been released, with node:http(s) now supporting proxies, OpenSSL 3.5, and --experimental-wasm-modulesÂ unflagged.

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ•¹ï¸ LLM whisperer Simon Willison shows off how he used the new GLM-4.5 Air model running locally on his MacBook Pro to implement a JavaScript 'Space Invaders' game in one shot. You can play it here.

  • npm now lets you securely publish npm packages from CI/CD workflows using OpenID Connect (OIDC) forÂ authentication.

  • ğŸ“Š The Stack Overflow 2025 survey results are out, and JavaScript sits at #1 in the most used languages, React holds the top frontend library spot, with jQuery at numberÂ two.

  • Tailwind Plus has added support for vanilla JavaScript â€“ no Vue or React needed.

RELEASES:

  • â­ pnpm 10.14 â€“ The alternative, efficient packageÂ manager adds the ability to declare a Node.js, Deno or Bun version in package.json and have it installed and pinnedÂ automatically.

  • Node-RED 4.1 â€“ Powerful JS-based low-code flow-based platform for building event-drivenÂ apps.

  • Ionic 8.7 â€“ Cross-platform mobile app development framework.

  • Storybook 9.1 â€“ Frontend component and UIÂ workshop.

  • TypeScript 5.9 RC â€“ The final release is imminent (most likely laterÂ today).

  • ESLint v9.32.0, Preact 10.27, Angular 20.1.4, Deno 2.4.3, React 19.1.1

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

â–¶Â Â Zod vs. Valibot: A JS/TS Validator Battle â€” You know itâ€™s good when the creator of Zod comments: â€œincredible video. honestly blown away by how succinct and clear you made everything.â€ (12Â minutes.)

Jack Herrington

Compile Svelte 5 in Your Head â€” Svelte does things a little differently to most UI frameworks by compiling code to components ahead-of-time, but what is it actually doing at the codeÂ level?

Tan Li Hau

Choosing The Right SaaS Architecture: Multi-Tenant Vs. Single-Tenant â€” Choosing between multi-tenant and single-tenant? This guide breaks down the tradeoffsÂ clearly.

Clerk sponsor

Logical Assignment Operators in JavaScript: Small Syntax, Big Wins â€” A handy post if you need to get a grip on your ||=, &&= andÂ ??=s.

Matt Smith

Making Sense of the Performance Extensibility API â€” The Performance Extensibility API allows us to create custom tracks in Chrome DevToolsâ€™ Performance panel â€” hereâ€™s how to make use ofÂ it.

Harry Roberts

ğŸ“º The Creator of Bun on Building Bun and its Node.js Compatibility Patrick Akil and Jarred Sumner

ğŸ“„ The Multi-Repository TypeScript Problem â€“ Solving cross-repo typeÂ safety. David Moores

ğŸ“„ vi.mock is a Footgun: Why vi.spyOn Should Be Your Default Brendan McLoughlin

ğŸ“„ How to Build 2D Game-Style Physics with Matter.js and React Native Skia Daniel Friyia (Expo Blog)

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Dependency Cruiser 17: A Way to Visualize Dependencies â€” If you want a look at the output, thereâ€™s a whole page of graphs for popular, real world projects including Chalk, Yarn, andÂ React.

Sander Verweij

TanStack DB: The Embedded Client Database for TanStack Query â€” One for team React! TanStackâ€¯DB is an embedded clientâ€‘side database that uses differential dataflow to power live, relational queries, subâ€‘ms incremental updates, and optimistic writes. This post is a great pitch, and the first beta is availableÂ now.

Kyle Mathews and Sam Willis

Connect Performance and Reliability to User Engagement â€” With Embrace, see where technical issues cause dropoff, along with attribute correlations to surface affectedÂ cohorts.

Embrace sponsor

AudioTee.js: macOS System Audio Capture for Node.js â€” Wrapping around an (included) Swift-powered binary, this captures Mac system audio output and emits it as PCM encoded chunks at regular intervals. GitHubÂ repo.

Nick Payne

  • Ghost 6.0 RC â€“ The popular Node.js-powered blogging / publishing platform approaches its next majorÂ release.

  • Ink 6.1 â€“ Use React to build CLIÂ apps, as used by Claude Code, Gemini CLI, and many other apps.

  • Cytoscape.js 3.33 â€“ Graph theory/network visualization and analysisÂ library.

  • eslint-plugin-vue 10.4 â€“ Official ESLint plugin for Vue.js.Â (Homepage.)

  • Axios 1.11 â€“ Long-standing, promise-based isomorphic HTTPÂ client.

  • InversifyJS 7.7 â€“ Lightweight inversion of controlÂ container.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Dropbox, Wiz, Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

ğŸ” Discover KeyLines - a scalable JavaScript graph visualization toolkit that turns complex data into actionableÂ insights.

ğŸÂ Some Bonus Items

  • Google has unveiled a new open-licensed code font called Google Sans Code. It has a 'soft' feel to it and is inspired by Google's branding. It's available on Google Fonts too, if you want to quickly plug it into a site.

  • NPKILL is a popular tool for digging into, and cleaning up, those heavy node_modules folders you've accumulated. v1.0 is nearly here and its author is thinking about how it could be extended to cleaning up other types of clutter.

  • Pete Matsyburka demonstrates how just a few lines of code can make sites load faster, thanks to the Speculation Rules API (currently only supported by Chromium-based browsers).

  • Got a big JavaScript project that needs some serious attention from someone experienced? npm creator Isaac Z. Schlueter is available for hire.

  • ğŸ“º If you've never thought about what might go into making a text editor, â–¶ï¸Â Computerphile's latest video will be an eye opener.

  • I have to admire someone who builds their blog using C preprocessor macros.
